Est. 2022 — O'Hare International

I found her on Carousel 4 at 2:14 AM — a hand-painted porcelain doll, wrapped in a JCPenney bag, tucked inside a suitcase that had been circling for nine hours. Nobody came back. I kept thinking about the hands that packed her, how carefully they must have nestled her between the socks and the toiletries. I was a baggage handler. I am a baggage handler. I just also run an auction now, because someone has to stand between the lost and the landfill.

Previous Owner Outreach Program

Before We Auction, We Look

Every bag that enters our system gets 90 days. Ninety days of database cross-referencing, airline manifest requests, social media keyword trawling, and sometimes just staring at a luggage tag and hoping. We are underfunded. We are three people and a shared Google Sheet. The airlines do not help. The TSA does not help. But we have reunited a grandmother's ashes with her family in Tulsa, and we once tracked down a man in Reykjavik using nothing but a dry-cleaning receipt and a library card. We are not efficient. But we are stubborn.

From The Carousel Floor

Auctioneer's Notes

2024.11.03 — LOT #7831

Someone's Entire Spice Collection, Labeled in Armenian

Forty-two glass jars, each one hand-labeled in neat Armenian script with a second label in English taped underneath — as if the owner knew they'd need to explain themselves at customs but refused to erase the original language. The suitcase smelled like a kitchen that loved you. Sumac, za'atar, dried barberries in a Ziploc. I held the bag of barberries for a long time. Someone's mother packed these. I am certain of it. Current bid: $340. I hope the buyer cooks with them.

2024.10.17 — LOT #8204

The Suitcase That Was Just Books and a Single House Key

No clothes. No toiletries. Just twenty-three paperbacks — mostly sci-fi, a few self-help titles with cracked spines, one copy of The Prophet with every other page dog-eared — and a single brass house key on a plain ring. No tag on the key. No address in any of the books. Whoever packed this bag was either moving in or moving out, and either way they decided the books mattered more than the shirts. I respect that completely. I also find it devastating. Bidding starts at $45.

Regulatory Framework

Yes, This Is Legal

1. DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY — 49 U.S.C. § 44901 et seq.
All unclaimed baggage is held for a minimum of 90 days per federal aviation regulation before disposition. Airlines transfer custody to licensed salvage operators under CFR Title 14, Part 254.4. We maintain chain-of-custody documentation for every item processed. No, you cannot skip the 90 days. We tried asking.
2. TSA SCREENING COMPLIANCE — REF: TSA-2019-0001-0042
All items are re-screened before auction per TSA Security Directive 1544-09-06. Prohibited items are surrendered to local law enforcement. This includes the surprising number of swords people check in their luggage. We do not auction the swords. We wish we could auction the swords.
3. PERSONAL IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION (PII) HANDLING — PROTOCOL ULA-PII-07
All documents, IDs, credit cards, and items containing PII are destroyed or returned to issuing agencies before auction. Photographs are redacted. Diaries are not read (officially). Letters are sealed in opaque evidence bags and auctioned only as "sealed correspondence, contents unknown." This is the hardest part of the job.
4. BIOHAZARD & PERISHABLE GOODS — REF: OSHA 29 CFR 1910.1030
Perishable items are disposed of within 72 hours of custody transfer. Yes, someone once checked an entire wheel of Gruyère. No, it did not survive the 90-day hold. Biohazard protocols apply to medical supplies, unmarked liquids, and that one suitcase from Terminal 5 that we do not discuss.
5. AUCTION LICENSING — STATE OF ILLINOIS, LICENSE #AUC-2022-04417
Unclaimed Luggage Auction Stream operates under Illinois Auction License Act (225 ILCS 407). All sales are final. Buyer's premium: 12%. Amelia Stone, licensed auctioneer #IL-04417. She got her license on a Tuesday and cried in the DMV parking lot, not because it was hard but because it meant this was actually happening.
6. REUNIFICATION PRIORITY PROTOCOL — INTERNAL REF: ULA-REUN-001
Before any lot enters the auction queue, it must clear the reunification review. Items with high sentimental probability (photographs, handwritten materials, children's belongings, religious items) receive an additional 30-day search extension. This is not required by law. This is required by us.

We take this seriously because someone packed these bags with their hands.
